statements.name: PROC SVDD
statements.description: The SVDD procedure implements the support vector data description (SVDD) algorithm (Tax and Duin 2004). SVDD is a one-class classification technique that is useful in applications where data that belong to one class are abundant but data about any other class are scarce or missing. Fraud detection, equipment health monitoring, and process control are some examples of application areas where the majority of the data belong to one class. You can use SVDD to model such one-class data and subsequently use the model to perform outlier detection.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Names the input data table for PROC SVDD to use. The default is the most recently created data table. CAS-libref.data-table is a two-level name, where

arguments.name: NBINS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of bins to display, where number must be an integer greater than 2. By default, NBINS=20.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the generation of ODS outputs. If you specify this option, no ODS tables are generated.

arguments.name: NTHREADS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of threads to use for the computation. The default value is the number of CPUs available in the machine.

arguments.name: OUTLIER_FRACTION=
arguments.description: Specifies the expected fraction of the training data that consists of outliers, where number must be a real number between 0 and 1.

arguments.name: OUTSV=
arguments.description: Specifies the output data to contain the training data observations that are identified as support vectors, the corresponding value of the Lagrange multiplier (column _SVDDALPHA_), and an indicator (column _SVDDOUTLIER_) that flags the position of the support vectors relative to the data boundary. Support vectors whose _SVDDOUTLIER_ value is 0 fall on the data boundary, and support vectors whose _SVDDOUTLIER_ value is 1 fall outside the data boundary. CAS-libref.data-table is a two-level name, where CAS-libref refers to the caslib and session identifier, and data-table specifies the name of the output data table.

arguments.name: SCORE
arguments.description: Scores the observations in the data table that is specified in the DATA= option and generates a frequency table of _SVDDDISTANCE_ values.

arguments.name: STANDARDIZE
arguments.description: Standardizes the variables that are specified in the INPUT statement with LEVEL=INTERVAL, by subtracting their mean and dividing by their standard deviation.

arguments.name: USECONSTANTCOLUMN
arguments.description: Uses variables that have constant values for SVDD scoring. By default, the variables that have constant values are ignored. This option is useful in scenarios where certain variables have constant value in the training data, but variation in the values of those variables is expected in the scoring data. This option ensures that variables with constant values are used for scoring.

statements.name: CODE
statements.description: The CODE statement generates SAS DATA step code that mimics the computations that are performed. The generated SAS DATA step code can be used for scoring new observations. Only one CODE statement is processed. If you specify multiple CODE statements, only the first one is used. The CODE statement is optional. If you do not include a CODE statement, no score code is generated.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: Specifies the filename of the file to write the SAS score code to.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement lists one or more variables to be copied from the input data table to the output data tables that are specified in the OUTSV= option in the PROC SVDD statement and the RSTORE= option in the SAVESTATE statement.

statements.name: INPUT
statements.description: The INPUT statement specifies the names of variables to be used in training. Only interval, binary, and nominal variables are accepted. If you want to use different options for different variables, you can specify multiple INPUT statements.

arguments.name: LEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the specified input variables are continuous or categorical.

arguments.name: INTERVAL
arguments.description: Specifies that the input variables are continuous.

arguments.name: NOMINAL
arguments.description: Specifies that the input variables are categorical.

statements.name: KERNEL
statements.description: The KERNEL statement specifies the type of kernel and any associated parameters to be used during training. Only the radial basis kernel function is supported.

arguments.name: RBF
arguments.description: [kernel-type] Uses a radial basis function (also known as the Gaussian kernel function) during training.

arguments.name: BW=
arguments.description: [kernel-parameter]

statements.name: SAVESTATE
statements.description: The SAVESTATE statement creates an analytic store for the model and saves it as a binary object in a data table. You can use the analytic store in the ASTORE procedure to score new data.

arguments.name: RSTORE=
arguments.description: Specifies the filename of the file in which to save the analytic store. CAS-libref.data-table is a two-level name, where CAS-libref refers to the caslib and session identifier, and data-table specifies the name of the output data table.

statements.name: SOLVER
statements.description: The SOLVER statement specifies the type of optimization solver for SVDD training.

arguments.name: ACTSET
arguments.description: Uses the active-set solver for SVDD training.

arguments.name: STOCHS
arguments.description: Uses a stochastic subset solver for SVDD training.

arguments.name: CTOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the tolerance value that is used for detecting convergence of the center, where number must be a real number greater than 0. To obtain a solution more quickly, specify a higher value for number. By default, CTOL=1E–2.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations of the solver, where number must be an integer greater than 0. To obtain a solution more quickly, specify a lower value for number. By default, MAXITER is set to 25 for the active-set solver and 200 for the stochastic subset solver.

arguments.name: MAXSV=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of support vectors, where number must be an integer greater than 0. To obtain a solution more quickly, specify a lower value for number. By default, MAXSV=3500.

arguments.name: NMATCH=
arguments.description: Specifies a convergence criterion for the stochastic solver, where number must be an integer greater than 0. If the radius and center values converge for number of consecutive iterations, then convergence is declared. By default, NMATCH=5. To obtain a solution more quickly, specify a lower value for number.

arguments.name: NSAMP=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of observations that are sampled in each iteration of the stochastic solver, where number must be an integer greater than 0. To obtain a solution more quickly, specify a lower value for number. By default, NSAMP=10.

arguments.name: RTOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the tolerance value that is used to detect convergence of threshold value, where number must be a real number greater than 0. To obtain a solution more quickly, specify a higher value for number. By default, RTOL=1E–2.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Specifies a seed value that is used for selecting a random sample, where number must be an integer. The default value of SEED is based on the system clock. If you want reproducible results, specify an integer for number.

arguments.name: STOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the tolerance value for the solver, where number must be a real number greater than 0. To obtain a solution more quickly, specify a higher value for number. By default, STOL=1E–6.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: The WEIGHT statement names a variable in the training data that specifies the weight to be assigned to each observation. The values of variable must be nonnegative. Observations that have higher weight have a better chance of being designated as support vectors.
